segment.source: Deploy Surface app with Windows Store for Business (Surface)
segment.target: Deploy Surface app with Windows Store for Business (Surface)

segment.source: Find out how to add and download Surface app with Windows Store for Business, as well as install Surface app with PowerShell and MDT.
segment.target: Find out how to add and download Surface app with Windows Store for Business, as well as install Surface app with PowerShell and MDT.

segment.source: Deploy Surface app with Windows Store for Business
segment.target: Deploy Surface app with Windows Store for Business

segment.source: The Surface app is a lightweight Windows Store app that provides control of many Surface-specific settings and options, including:
segment.target: The Surface app is a lightweight Windows Store app that provides control of many Surface-specific settings and options, including:

segment.source: Enable or disable the Windows button on the Surface device
segment.target: Enable or disable the Windows button on the Surface device

segment.source: Adjust the sensitivity of a Surface Pen
segment.target: Adjust the sensitivity of a Surface Pen

segment.source: Customize Surface Pen button actions
segment.target: Customize Surface Pen button actions

segment.source: Enable or disable Surface audio enhancements
segment.target: Enable or disable Surface audio enhancements

segment.source: Quick access to support documentation and information for your device
segment.target: Quick access to support documentation and information for your device

segment.source: If your organization is preparing images that will be deployed to your Surface devices, you may want to include the Surface app (formerly called the Surface Hub) in your imaging and deployment process instead of requiring users of each individual device to download and install the app from the Windows Store or your Windows Store for Business.
segment.target: If your organization is preparing images that will be deployed to your Surface devices, you may want to include the Surface app (formerly called the Surface Hub) in your imaging and deployment process instead of requiring users of each individual device to download and install the app from the Windows Store or your Windows Store for Business.

segment.source: Surface app overview
segment.target: Surface app overview

segment.source: The Surface app is available as a free download from the Windows Store.
segment.target: The Surface app is available as a free download from the Windows Store.

segment.source: Users can download and install it from the Windows Store, but if your organization uses Windows Store for Business instead, you will need to add it to your store’s inventory and possibly include the app as part of your Windows deployment process.
segment.target: Users can download and install it from the Windows Store, but if your organization uses Windows Store for Business instead, you will need to add it to your store’s inventory and possibly include the app as part of your Windows deployment process.

segment.source: These processes are discussed throughout this article.
segment.target: These processes are discussed throughout this article.

segment.source: For more information about Windows Store for Business, see Windows Store for Business in the Windows TechCenter.
segment.target: For more information about Windows Store for Business, see Windows Store for Business in the Windows TechCenter.

segment.source: Add Surface app to a Windows Store for Business account
segment.target: Add Surface app to a Windows Store for Business account

segment.source: Before users can install or deploy an app from a company’s Windows Store for Business account, the desired app(s) must first be made available and licensed to the users of a business.
segment.target: Before users can install or deploy an app from a company’s Windows Store for Business account, the desired app(s) must first be made available and licensed to the users of a business.

segment.source: If you have not already done so, create a Windows Store for Business account.
segment.target: If you have not already done so, create a Windows Store for Business account.

segment.source: Log on to the portal.
segment.target: Log on to the portal.

segment.source: Enable offline licensing: click Settings->Account Information, and then select the Show offline licensed apps to people shopping in the store checkbox, as shown in Figure 1.
segment.target: Enable offline licensing: click Settings->Account Information, and then select the Show offline licensed apps to people shopping in the store checkbox, as shown in Figure 1.

segment.source: For more information about Windows Store for Business app licensing models, see Apps in Windows Store for Business.
segment.target: For more information about Windows Store for Business app licensing models, see Apps in Windows Store for Business.

segment.source: Show offline licenses apps checkbox
segment.target: Show offline licenses apps checkbox

segment.source: Figure 1.
segment.target: Figure 1.

segment.source: Enable apps for offline use
segment.target: Enable apps for offline use

segment.source: Add Surface app to your Windows Store for Business account by following this procedure:
segment.target: Add Surface app to your Windows Store for Business account by following this procedure:

segment.source: Click the Shop menu.
segment.target: Click the Shop menu.

segment.source: In the search box, type Surface app, and then click the search icon.
segment.target: In the search box, type Surface app, and then click the search icon.

segment.source: After the Surface app is presented in the search results, click the app’s icon.
segment.target: After the Surface app is presented in the search results, click the app’s icon.

segment.source: You are presented with a choice (select Online or Offline), as shown in Figure 2.
segment.target: You are presented with a choice (select Online or Offline), as shown in Figure 2.

segment.source: Select the Offline licensing mode and add the app to your inventory
segment.target: Select the Offline licensing mode and add the app to your inventory

segment.source: Figure 2.
segment.target: Figure 2.

segment.source: Select the Offline licensing mode and add the app to your inventory
segment.target: Select the Offline licensing mode and add the app to your inventory

segment.source: Click Offline to select the Offline licensing mode.
segment.target: Click Offline to select the Offline licensing mode.

segment.source: Click Get the app to add the app to your Windows Store for Business inventory.
segment.target: Click Get the app to add the app to your Windows Store for Business inventory.

segment.source: As shown in Figure 3, you’ll see a dialog box that prompts you to acknowledge that offline apps can be deployed using a management tool or downloaded from the company’s inventory page in their private store.
segment.target: As shown in Figure 3, you’ll see a dialog box that prompts you to acknowledge that offline apps can be deployed using a management tool or downloaded from the company’s inventory page in their private store.

segment.source: Offline-licensed app acknowledgement window
segment.target: Offline-licensed app acknowledgement window

segment.source: Figure 3.
segment.target: Figure 3.

segment.source: Offline-licensed app acknowledgement
segment.target: Offline-licensed app acknowledgement

segment.source: Click OK.
segment.target: Click OK.

segment.source: Download Surface app from a Windows Store for Business account
segment.target: Download Surface app from a Windows Store for Business account

segment.source: After you add an app to the Windows Store for Business account in Offline mode, you can download and add the app as an AppxBundle to a deployment share.
segment.target: After you add an app to the Windows Store for Business account in Offline mode, you can download and add the app as an AppxBundle to a deployment share.

segment.source: Log on to the Windows Store for Business account at https://businessstore.microsoft.com.
segment.target: Log on to the Windows Store for Business account at https://businessstore.microsoft.com.

segment.source: Click the Manage->Inventory menu.
segment.target: Click the Manage->Inventory menu.

segment.source: A list of all apps in your company’s private store is displayed, including the Surface app you added in the Add Surface app to a Windows Store for Business account section of this article.
segment.target: A list of all apps in your company’s private store is displayed, including the Surface app you added in the Add Surface app to a Windows Store for Business account section of this article.

segment.source: Under Actions, click the ellipsis (…), and then click Download for offline use for the Surface app.
segment.target: Under Actions, click the ellipsis (…), and then click Download for offline use for the Surface app.

segment.source: Select the desired Platform and Architecture options from the available selections for the selected app, as shown in Figure 4.
segment.target: Select the desired Platform and Architecture options from the available selections for the selected app, as shown in Figure 4.

segment.source: Example of the AppxBundle package
segment.target: Example of the AppxBundle package

segment.source: Figure 4.
segment.target: Figure 4.

segment.source: Download the AppxBundle package for an app
segment.target: Download the AppxBundle package for an app

segment.source: Click Download.
segment.target: Click Download.

segment.source: The AppxBundle package will be downloaded.
segment.target: The AppxBundle package will be downloaded.

segment.source: Make sure you note the path of the downloaded file because you’ll need that later in this article.
segment.target: Make sure you note the path of the downloaded file because you’ll need that later in this article.

segment.source: Click either the Encoded license or Unencoded license option.
segment.target: Click either the Encoded license or Unencoded license option.

segment.source: Use the Encoded license option with management tools like System Center Configuration Manager or when you use Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer (Windows ICD).
segment.target: Use the Encoded license option with management tools like System Center Configuration Manager or when you use Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer (Windows ICD).

segment.source: Select the Unencoded license option when you use Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM) or deployment solutions based on imaging, including the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT).
segment.target: Select the Unencoded license option when you use Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM) or deployment solutions based on imaging, including the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT).

segment.source: Click Generate to generate and download the license for the app.
segment.target: Click Generate to generate and download the license for the app.

segment.source: Make sure you note the path of the license file because you’ll need that later in this article.
segment.target: Make sure you note the path of the license file because you’ll need that later in this article.

segment.source: Note: When you download an app for offline use, such as the Surface app, you may notice a section at the bottom of the page labeled Required frameworks.
segment.target: Note: When you download an app for offline use, such as the Surface app, you may notice a section at the bottom of the page labeled Required frameworks.

segment.source: Your target computers must have the frameworks installed for the app to run, so you may need to repeat the download process for each of the required frameworks for your architecture (either x86 or x64) and also include them as part of your Windows deployment discussed later in this article.
segment.target: Your target computers must have the frameworks installed for the app to run, so you may need to repeat the download process for each of the required frameworks for your architecture (either x86 or x64) and also include them as part of your Windows deployment discussed later in this article.

segment.source: Figure 5 shows the required frameworks for the Surface app.
segment.target: Figure 5 shows the required frameworks for the Surface app.

segment.source: Required frameworks for the Surface app
segment.target: Required frameworks for the Surface app

segment.source: Figure 5.
segment.target: Figure 5.

segment.source: Required frameworks for the Surface app
segment.target: Required frameworks for the Surface app

segment.source: To download the required frameworks for the Surface app, follow these steps:
segment.target: To download the required frameworks for the Surface app, follow these steps:

segment.source: Click the Download button under Microsoft.VCLibs.140.00_14.0.23816.0_x64__8wekyb3d8bbwe.
segment.target: Click the Download button under Microsoft.VCLibs.140.00_14.0.23816.0_x64__8wekyb3d8bbwe.

segment.source: This downloads the Microsoft.VCLibs.140.00_14.0.23816.0_x64__8wekyb3d8bbwe.Appx file to your specified folder.
segment.target: This downloads the Microsoft.VCLibs.140.00_14.0.23816.0_x64__8wekyb3d8bbwe.Appx file to your specified folder.

segment.source: Click the Download button under Microsoft.NET.Native.Runtime.1.1_1.1.23406.0_x64__8wekyb3d8bbwe.
segment.target: Click the Download button under Microsoft.NET.Native.Runtime.1.1_1.1.23406.0_x64__8wekyb3d8bbwe.

segment.source: This downloads the Microsoft.NET.Native.Runtime.1.1_1.1.23406.0_x64__8wekyb3d8bbwe.Appx file to your specified folder.
segment.target: This downloads the Microsoft.NET.Native.Runtime.1.1_1.1.23406.0_x64__8wekyb3d8bbwe.Appx file to your specified folder.

segment.source: Note: Only the 64-bit (x64) version of each framework is required for Surface devices.
segment.target: Note: Only the 64-bit (x64) version of each framework is required for Surface devices.

segment.source: Surface devices are native 64-bit UEFI devices and are not compatible with 32-bit (x86) versions of Windows that would require 32-bit frameworks.
segment.target: Surface devices are native 64-bit UEFI devices and are not compatible with 32-bit (x86) versions of Windows that would require 32-bit frameworks.

segment.source: Install Surface app on your computer with PowerShell
segment.target: Install Surface app on your computer with PowerShell

segment.source: The following procedure provisions the Surface app onto your computer and makes it available for any user accounts created on the computer afterwards.
segment.target: The following procedure provisions the Surface app onto your computer and makes it available for any user accounts created on the computer afterwards.

segment.source: Using the procedure described in the How to download Surface app from a Windows Store for Business account section of this article, download the Surface app AppxBundle and license file.
segment.target: Using the procedure described in the How to download Surface app from a Windows Store for Business account section of this article, download the Surface app AppxBundle and license file.

segment.source: Begin an elevated PowerShell session.
segment.target: Begin an elevated PowerShell session.

segment.source: Note: If you don’t run PowerShell as an Administrator, the session won’t have the required permissions to install the app.
segment.target: Note: If you don’t run PowerShell as an Administrator, the session won’t have the required permissions to install the app.

segment.source: In the elevated PowerShell session, copy and paste the following command:
segment.target: In the elevated PowerShell session, copy and paste the following command:

segment.source: Where is the folder where you downloaded the AppxBundle and license file from the Windows Store for Business account.
segment.target: Where is the folder where you downloaded the AppxBundle and license file from the Windows Store for Business account.

segment.source: For example, if you downloaded the files to c:\Temp, the command you run is:
segment.target: For example, if you downloaded the files to c:\Temp, the command you run is:
